titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the New-York Historical Society Collection of Prints from the Works Progress Administration, Federal Art Project
1935-1943
PR 345
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-01-16T13:39-0500

did.unittitle: New-York Historical Society collection of prints from the Works Progress Administration, Federal Art Project
did.abstract: The collection includes nine prints produced by eight artists in connection with the Works Progress Administration's Federal Art Project (1935-1943), specifically from New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection includes nine prints produced by eight artists in connection with the Works Progress Administration's Federal Art Program, specifically from New York City. The specific artists and works included in the collection are detailed in the container list. Generally, the works focus on people, rather than structures or landscapes, in urban settings such as street scenes, getting tattoos, street cart sales, and searching through a garbage can.

accruals.head: Accruals Note
accruals.p: Additional related prints may be acquired by purchase or donation in the future and added to the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by artist name.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Federal Art Project (1935-1943) was a Depression-era relief program run by the Works Progress Administration. The art project employed thousands of artists across the United States to create paintings, murals, photographs, and other art forms for the public. This collection includes a relatively small number of the thousands of "portable" works, specifically prints from New York City, created during the program.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: The prints were purchased over time by N-YHS. Dates for each are noted in the container list.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by archivist Larry Weimer in December 2017. The collection was formed at that time, primarily by transferring prints from the Printmaker File (PR 58) into this new collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials Note
relatedmaterial.p: This collection holds only prints created under the auspices of the Federal Art Project. Some of the artists included here can also be found in other N-YHS collections unrelated to the Federal Art Project. See N-YHS's Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections' Printmaker File (PR 58).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as New-York Historical Society collection of prints from the Works Progress Administration, Federal Art Project, PR 345, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes wood engraving Sweet Potato Man (1936). Purchased 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes lithograph Harlem Street Scene (circa 1936-1942). Purchase, November 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes etching East River (1937). Purchase, November 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes color screenprint Going to Work (1935). Purchase, November 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes lithographs Buried Treasure (1939) and General Seminary (1936). Treasure was purchased November 2016 and Seminary was purchased October 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes wood engraving Lumber Yard (1935-1943). Purchase, October 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes lithograph Tattoo Artist (ca. 1936-1939), depicting the interior of Apache Harry's tattoo shop at 22 Bowery. Purchase, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes lithograph Fulton Street, Brooklyn (circa 1935). Purchase, November 2015.
